title: How eBay began as a hobby ... offering, for sale, a broken pen! | Meridian
text:
Twenty five MILLION sellers ... 157 MILLION buyers ... auction site eBay started from humble beginnings, as a hobby, but it's now one of the biggest e-commerce firms. And, this month, it celebrates its 20th anniversary.
Computer programmer Pierre Omidyar began the business as a sole trader in 1995, listing a broken laser pointer pen as his first item for sale - and being stunned to find a buyer.
The US-headquartered giant now has a stock market value of more than 32 billion US dollars (£21 billion).
20 year anniversary of eBay 18 million website 'visitors' every month 200,000 businesses now trade through eBay Its App has been downloaded 280 million times Thingimijigs, one of eBay's success stories Credit: PA Images There are now more than 2,000 eBay millionaires in Britain alone as savvy sellers - from so-called 'mumpreneurs' to graduates - tap into the site's unique market where there's a buyer for almost anything.
Academic and business forecaster Professor Richard Scase said: "Governments try to create entrepreneurs and generally fail. Over the past 20 years eBay has done it for more than 25 million sellers."
He added that eBay has transformed business and retailing, "destroying the relevance of geographical and national boundaries".
"With tablets, laptops and smartphones, teenagers through to pensioners can be international traders," he said.
One of eBay's recent British business successes includes children's gifts and accessories firm Thingimijigs, set up by mumpreneur Rachael White 10 years ago from her kitchen table with just an eBay account and £200.
The 43-year-old left her career at supermarket Morrisons to launch on her own and now makes more than £1 million in annual revenues.
More than half the small online retailers on eBay's UK marketplace are now global - exporting to four or more different continents.
The site has played a key part in enabling firms to become exporters without the costs and infrastructure usually needed to trade internationally.
